Comment: The new director needs to be very knowledgeable and conscientious about the public health effects of polluters coming from industry which needs to be  regulated stringently to make sure filters and other devices are firmly in place to limit the particles of pollution going into our commons: air, water, soil. He/she needs to put a strict follow-up program in place to monitor industry for compliance. Focus on getting diesel exhaust to an absolute minimum is imperative. "Cleaner air" should become " cleanest air, soil and water." Thank you for putting our health first!

We need someone who recognizes that allowing businesses to externalize costs by dumping harmful contaminants in our air and water is not what citizens want. It is time to require that polluters fix the problems they create and profit from and prevent more damage.  Resident have clearly stated they want air and water that is safe and usable. Permitting harmful dumping of contaminants needs to no longer by enabled by DEQ

Organization: Oregon Bass and Pan Fish, PHCAG
Comment: The new head of the DEQ must be a qualified scientist, able to manage the DEQ and withstand political and business pressures.  Be given the staff and the money to do the job. Without the above there is no reason to bother with a DEQ.

Organization: Oregon Bass and Pan Fish, PHCAG
Comment: The new head of the DEQ must be a qualified scientist, able to manage the DEQ and withstand political and business pressures.  Be given the staff and the money to do the job. Without the above there is no reason to bother with a DEQ.

The new DEQ director needs to be scientist who will ensure that the health of the environment is the priority. That his/her work protects the well-being of both human and wildlife existence and habitat. He must maintain integrity concerning environmental health and be given autonomy to be protected against legislative influences as well as pressure from industry. In order to achieve this, perhaps as the director requires an assistant, an attorney familiar with both environmental  and business law and not just the staff attorney who gets to do all the legal work. 
This person should be given enough financial and staff support to oversee site projects throughout the state and enough qualified staff to thoroughly maintain the NPDES permits as well as similar projects. The director must have a full collection of qualified staff to support these achievements. He should be selected from an unbiased arena and not affiliated with any businesses that would create a â€œconflict of interestâ€� either financially or prejudice by departing from what is best for the health of the biota or humans from former affiliations. 
The director must become familiar with project sites like superfund sites, mining sites, hazardous chemicals and situations. The director must familiarize his/herself about Portlandâ€™s air problems, river contamination, mining operations, potential of Hanford nuclear problems as well as a thorough briefing on the effects of upcoming â€œCascadiaâ€� earthquake from DOGAMI. The director should also learn about the water problems in Klamath Falls as well as any problems with all Oregonâ€™s rivers and coastal problems. 
The director needs to become familiar with the problems with how far behind Oregonâ€™s law regarding diesel trucks, exhaust and lack of filtering. Also, the director should know about vehicular greenhouse gas rules against challenges from the auto industry. 
While the economic considerations should be recognized and handled with care, kowtowing to industry or the PBA should not be in the job description.
The director should not be a PR person like Nina de Concini or Alex Liverman. They do not care about the environment or the citizens of Oregon. The director should care about both. Rather look to DEQ employees like Kevin Parrett or Matt McClincy. Both are qualified and effective. So would Rhett Lawrence of the Sierra Club. Thank you.

A serious problem exists from a local service station,just blocks from most of our citizens. Hundreds of tires,strewn about,with water inside, supporting mosquito larvae,and untold amounts of mosquitos. Owner is non responsive.

Because many others will speak so articulately, I cannot offer a better description of what a new Director should be. My suggestion is for a different approach altogether.

Bear with me as I point out your short-term dilemma: in only a few months this agency will submit budgets to the Legislature. 

So even if you found the perfect candidate tomorrow, you don't have enough time to bring her on board such that she could make the kind of contribution that DEQ will need, to make their case for the funding they must have.

So set aside this nationwide search for now; instead of paying these headhunters their worthy, yet hefty, fees, dedicate some of that money to supporting your new Deputy Director, to whom you granted Full Authority.

Crazy idea? Maybe so, but there's a recent precedent.

The PDC, the Portland Development Commission, named a new Executive Director last month. After a similar nationwide search, they decided to promote their current Deputy Director to the job, as she was doing such a good job in the interim.

The next DEQ head needs to be an advance degree candidate in environmental sciences who is also a communicator. Hiring a husband or wife of a current state employee reeks of nepotism and party advancement. The candidate must have skills beyond press and public manipulation, and management skills and must be a scientist with social skills. Such an individual must put the health needs of the public first above industry.   This is not a job to keep industry happy. This is a job thst ensures the quality of the environment and health of the citizens . Quality means excellent quality, not middling to poor quality.

We hope the new director has a degree related to environmental science and health; that they are a proven communicator to the public, that they are experienced in successfully running a like size and budget group and that they have both public and private sector experience.

I would like to see a DEQ Director who is:
> literate in and dedicated to the Precautionary Principle 
> well-versed in the scientific method and the work of actual scientists
> a silver-tongued, fierce, lion-hearted, proven advocate for public health and the health of the environment
> literate in climate change science
> completely unbeholden to industrial stakeholders

When it comes to industrial pollution, we have reached a saturation point. The old ways - dilution and mitigation - simply aren't going to cut it anymore. Diagnosed and undiagnosed Superfund sites and all their million little brothers and continued high-risk industrial practices will be our demise and have already meant the loss of species, damaged ecosystems, various untimely human cancers, chronic ailments, billions of dollars spent on imperfect clean-up operations, externalized medical costs, loss of revenue and productivity, etc etc. Our ignorance has preceded us and continues to trip us up. We have been cavalier and foolish in our approaches to resource extraction, pollution and waste handling. And hostile towards our scientists and environmentalists. It's gotta stop. I'd like a DEQ Director who knows that and gives a rip and has the savvy and eloquence to truly turn the boat; a Director who can the make the case - to Industry stakeholders, their employees and benefactors, and the State Legislature - for pollution prevention, responsibility for one's mess, and accountability to the Common Welfare. With all my everything I hope you find that person.  

I am also attaching a file for your recruitment firm. Please direct them to the "Contributors" pages i-iii where they will find a treasure trove of people who are public health and environmental advocates and who may be able to provide referrals, leads, and knowledgable input.

Closely representative of my vision of qualifications and skills. I would add to the second bullet point..."especially including successful enforcement of rules, laws...etc"
In "Education requirements," I would take out the word, "ideally." We need a science or health person in this job.

Please pick a person who believes in health based regulation. Not health risk but health based. The current tech based practices are not working. Precautionary Principle always. We can't let Industry police themselves any longer as we have seen they will not do whats best for the community. We also need a strong leader one that will stand up to big money and industry to actually clean up Oregon's air ,water and earth. A leader that will actually enforce rules and regulations.We are liars to pretend that Oregon is green. We have some of the worst air & water quality in the nation. The curtain has been pulled back and the time is now to hire strong leaders who know we need to keep health first. Health care costs so much more than healthy regulation.

Please hire a director who believes in health based regulation. Not health risk but health based. The current tech based rules and regs are not working. We need a strong leader who will actually stand up to big money and industry and enforce rules and regulation. We need a leader who will make sure that OHA does their job in making sure benchmarks for human health are current with new findings and studies of health impacts caused by toxics and pollution. The DEQ needs to do their job and clean up Oregon. I don't want "Cleaner" air Oregon I want CLEAN AIR OREGON.

I'm concerned that the EQC appears to be running this search process, crafting the position description, etc. Is that right? As someone who hires several positions a year, I don't understand the position description as stated, and question why people are conflating minimum requirements with preferred qualifications, etc. That's a short way of saying that I would recommend we use public resources intelligently and hire a search firm to help develop a position description and recruit well-qualified candidates. With a position this important, it seems like it would be well worth the investment.

Off the cuff I would recommend these as some of my MINIMUM qualifications (i.e. If you don't have it or cannot demonstrate it then you don't even move forward to an interview):

1. Masters degree or terminal degree (JD or PhD) with a focus in natural resource management, environmental science, or environmental policy.
2. Minimum five years of experience in senior to executive level management positions with supervisory and budgetary responsibilities.
3. Demonstrated track record of safeguarding natural resources and protecting the environment.
4. Demonstrated ability to navigate complex issues, mediate conflict, and maintain professional working relationships with diverse stakeholders.

Those to me are the basic, bare minimum. There might be one or two more, and then there's certainly lots of preferred qualifications to tack on. But you got to get those minimums right.

The new director needs to have a background in public health and NO conflicts of interests, IE, not a member of any business organizations, not a former member of any business organizations, not married to anybody in a business organization. The new director needs to have a history of protecting public health rather than catering to business interests.
Is there a forum for DEQ staff to weigh in on what they would like to see in a new DEQ Director?
